pullRequest.body:
This defines "continuously polynomial" (shortened to "cpolynomial") functions as a special cases of analytic functions: they are the functions that admit a development as a *finite* formal multilinear series. Then we prove their basic properties. The point of doing is this is that finite series are always summable, so we can remove the completeness assumptions in some results about analytic functions (differentiability for example). Examples of continuously polynomial functions include continuous multilinear maps, and functions defined by polynomials.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

> Ok oops, the file Polynomial.lean already existed in that directory. I'm surprised that vscode didn't protest when I tried to create a new file with that name.

The file was just merged into mathlib yesterday and wasn't in your local copy of mathlib, so no wonder VSCode doesn't complain ... It's about evaluations of Polynomial and MvPolynomial rather than MultilinearMap or Series, so you did the right thing to create a new file CPolynomial. I should have suggested the name CPolynomial earlier, because it's me who added the Polynomial file ... ðŸ˜…

> > Ok oops, the file Polynomial.lean already existed in that directory. I'm surprised that vscode didn't protest when I tried to create a new file with that name.
> 
> The file was just merged into mathlib yesterday and wasn't in your local copy of mathlib, so no wonder VSCode doesn't complain ... It's about evaluations of Polynomial and MvPolynomial rather than MultilinearMap or Series, so you did the right thing to create a new file CPolynomial. I should have suggested the name CPolynomial earlier, because it's me who added the Polynomial file ... ðŸ˜…

But do you understand why all the CI checks fail now ? My files compile locally, but now the "check that all files are imported" check fails, and then mathlib doesn't build. As I don't know what "check that all files are imported means", I am kind of stuck.
Also, the file `Polynomial.lean` should really prove that polynomials are `CPolynomial`, not just analytic, then you'll get infinite differentiability even if `B` is not complete.
Well I merged with master, I tried pushing again, CI still fails with an error message I don't understand...
Yeah it was the import in Calculus.FDeriv.Analytic, wasn't it. I finally figured it out, but looks like you got there just before me...
I think you also need to add the CPolynomial file to Mathlib.lean.
Oh, is that something that you need to do every time you add a new file ? Good to know.

If you click on the second "detail" you'll be led to [this page](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7350472056/job/20012191648?pr=9269) which shows what needs to be done. I think the bot used to suggest such fixes ...
I did click on the "details" page, but I didn't see any information that I could understand...
Yes it's not totally clear. It's presented in the form of a diff for you to apply, like the bot's [suggestion](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9269#discussion_r1437840750).
Also, CI still fails, and the bot seems to be suggesting that I remove CPolynomial from Mathlib.lean, or switch the order? It's making several suggestions and they don't seem very compatible.

> Yes it's not totally clear. It's presented in the form of a diff for you to apply, like the bot's [suggestion](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9269#discussion_r1437840750). Okay, well, now I see what you mean, but there was no way I was going to understand that on my own... I guess I'll know next time.
So let's see if I understand the suggestion this time. I think it wants me to move a line around. I thought the imports were in alphabetical order, but apparently not.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7473552513/job/20337931173)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7473552513/job/20337930636)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7473552513/job/20337930887)

Minor comments about docstrings. Otherwise, let's get this merged.

bors d+
Just pushed some improvements. Here are comments on what I did:

Minor comments about docstrings. Otherwise, let's get this merged.

bors d+
I think this warrants starting a new file. The current file is already quite a bit > 1000 lines, and you are adding another >500.

> I think this warrants starting a new file. The current file is already quite a bit > 1000 lines, and you are adding another >500.

Okay, so make a file called something like `Polynomial` and put all the modifications from the other two files in it ?
(By the way, I didn't do stability by composition, because there's not much I can add except an estimate for the degree of the composition, and that seemed like a lot of work for something that I'm not even sure we need yet.)

I implemented your suggestions and put the "finite powers series" stuff in a file `Polynomial.lean`, but left the things about derivatives in the same file as before (since they happen in a different part of the mathlib hierarchy). Apparently this has created a conflict ? I see an ominous message "This branch has conflicts that must be resolved", but I don't know what the conflict is.
Ok oops, the file `Polynomial.lean` already existed in that directory. I'm surprised that vscode didn't protest when I tried to create a new file with that name.

I *think* I got rid of the merge conflict, but now I get new CI fails, and I frankly have no idea what is going on.
I'm going for a walk, this is just frustrating me and I'm afraid I'll start doing stupid stuff again.

This lemma isn't actually used, but seems nice to have. I originally wanted to convert the nested tsum in `changeOrigin_eval_of_finite` into nested Finset.sum using this, but that would be more complicated and have less common with the existing `changeOrigin_eval`.
corrected the name
extracted lemma from both `changeOrigin_eval` and `changeOrigin_eval_of_finite`.
many golfs like this are done by reusing HasFPowerSeries lemmas
corrected two names according to naming convention (lemmas are snake case)
These lemmas can be easily obtained using dot notation and may be removed

It's true. I kept these lemmas (and wrote proofs that don't rely on the similar lemmas for analytic functions) because the proofs are mathematically much simpler in the finite case, so it bothered me to reduce to a more complicated statement. But if the proofs become just "use the statement for analytic functions", then I agree that the lemmas should be deleted.

I know you probably adapted the proof of the existing [HasFPowerSeriesOnBall.fderiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#HasFPowerSeriesOnBall.fderiv) (which assumes CompleteSpace), but I wonder why that statement doesn't use [FormalMultilinearSeries.shift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FormalMultilinearSeries.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.shift) ... I think we should look into proving they are equal.

Once we have this, I think the main goal of #9130 can be achieved by identifying `shift` with `linearDeriv` in the case of a FormalMultilinearSeries of a single term, right? We should probably add it the equality to the other file after this is merged.

> I know you probably adapted the proof of the existing [HasFPowerSeriesOnBall.fderiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#HasFPowerSeriesOnBall.fderiv) (which assumes CompleteSpace), but I wonder why that statement doesn't use [FormalMultilinearSeries.shift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FormalMultilinearSeries.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.shift) ... I think we should look into proving they are equal.

I don't think that they are equal. I tried proving that they are, and the expression used in `HasFPowerSeriesOnBall.fderiv` seems to scramble the variables more, as well as having an extra factor of `n+1` in degree `n`. The first point would not be surprising, as the only thing we know about the two formal multilinear series is that they have the same sum, which does not determine them (unless they are symmetric and we are in characteristic zero). The second point... well, are we sure that `FormalMultilinearSeries.shift` really is the Taylor series of the derivative ? The mathlib file says that it is but doesn't give any explanation or reference. I'll need a pen and paper to investigate more.

> Once we have this, I think the main goal of #9130 can be achieved by identifying `shift` with `linearDeriv` in the case of a FormalMultilinearSeries of a single term, right? We should probably add it the equality to the other file after this is merged.

I would be happy to make the definition of `linearDeriv` look more natural, but I don't understand what you mean here. What is a `FormalMultiliearSeries` of a single term, and how would you adapt the definition of `shift` so that it applies in the context of #9130, where you're working with multilinear maps ? Or do you mean that we should prove that the `FormalMultilinearSeries` of `f.linearDeriv` is equal to the shift of the `FormalMultilinearSeries` of `f` ? (I'm not sure that's true though.) 
By the way, I started rewriting the next step, i.e. the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic, [there](https://github.com/smorel394/ExteriorPowers/blob/master/ExteriorPowers/ContinuousMultilinearMapContDiff.lean). The things I am using so far fro #9130 are `domDomRestrict`, `toFormalMultilinearSeries_fixedDegree` (and its lemmas) and `toFormalMultilinearSeries_partialSum`. It totally forgot about `linearDeriv`, I should probably prove that it is indeed the FrÃ©chet derivative...

So what should I do with this suggestion ? As I said, `FormalMultilinearSeries.shift` is not equal to the formal power series of the derivative that is currently in mathlib. There are two issues:
(1) Formal power series are not unique, so we could at most expect the two formal power series to coincide on the diagonal. This is not a big issue, as we only care about the behavior on the diagonal, but if we want to use `shift` it means rewriting a pretty big proof.
(2) The normalization: usually Taylor series of functions have factors ${1}/{n!}$. Mathlib doesn't do that because it has to work in every characteristic, but I think that `shift` was defined with that normalization in mind. So if it is to be the formal power series of the derivative, its definition has to be changed, preferably with a comment explaining why. (Problem: I don't know what that would break.)

So in the end, it is probably possible to do something using a modified version of `FormalMultilinearSeries.shift`, but I'm not sure that it would justify the extra effort, because I don't know what we would gain. We already know that, if `f` is continuously polynomial of degree `n`, then its derivative is continuously polynomial of degree `n-1`. We can get more explicit formulas for `f'(x)` in particular cases using the degree `1` term of the formal multilinear series of `f` at `x`; I did that for continuous multilinear maps, for example.

Thanks. I looked into the definition of `shift` and it seems to be only currying the last coordinate, so it could only possibly work for a series whose terms are all symmetric multilinear forms. Even in that case, the nth term seems to be missing a factor of n. I think we should remove the claim that it's the derivative from the docstring.

Regarding the connection with linearDeriv, maybe the most general thing we can state and prove is that `linearDeriv` evaluate to the same thing as the `changeOriginSeries 1` of `toFormalMultilinearSeriesFixedDegree`. (Regarding the definition of `toFormalMultilinearSeriesFixedDegree`: I think you need to sum over powersetCard because you want a series development around an arbitrary point, but I think you can just define the series around the origin, which would just be a single term (a "homogeneous" CPolynomial), and then use changeOrigin of FormalMultilinearSeries rather than repeating the work.)

I tracked down the history and it appears the claim that `FormalMultilinearSeries.shift` is the derivative was added in [mathlib3#2012](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/commit/4637e5c85ccd5c0798574d87005f94bf15b01bb3#diff-019a55ce3884d457d49a227ddffcf48744c88c3d5abe700250b85a8325d61ff1R183-R187) originally. Do you agree the claim is problematic, @sgouezel?

I think the claim is correct: if for all `n` then `p (n+1)` is the derivative of `p n` (i.e., `p` is a Taylor series), then for all `n` one also has that `p (n+2)` is the derivative of `p (n+1)` (i.e., `p.shift` is a Taylor series, namely of the derivative of the original function). But there is indeed a catch, that for an analytic function its development as a power series does *not* coincide with its Taylor series (precisely because of the `n!` factor). Let `f x = \sum q_n (x, ..., x)` be a power series, where `q_n` is `n`-multilinear. Then its `n`-th derivative at the origin is given by `D^n f (0; v_1, ..., v_n) = \sum_\sigma q_n (v_{\sigma(1), ..., v_{\sigma(n)})` where the sum is over all permutations of `n` symbols. It has to be something like that, because `D^n f` is symmetric while `q_n` has no reason to be symmetric. And this explains nicely the multiplicity `n!` that shows up in dimension `1`, as the cardinality of the group of permutations of `n` symbols. Am I missing something here?

Hi Sebastien, I don't know about Junyan, but for me the problem with that claim in mathlib is not that it cannot be made mathematically correct. I will believe you when ou say that it can. The problem is that I don't find it helpful, for two reasons:
(1) I don't know what the sentence "If `p` corresponds to the Taylor series of a function" means mathematically, and this is not explained in the file, so I was not able to translate the claim intro a precise mathematical sentence. (When Junyan asked me to compare `p.shift` with the `FormalMultilinearSeries` for the derivative of the sum of `p`, I actually went and googled "Taylor series", and I was not enlightened.)
(2) The claim is not proved anywhere.

Your definition of Taylor series is weird and doesn't quite typecheck; surely (suppose we have a Taylor series in one variable) the derivative of $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}x^n$ is $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-1)!}x^{n-1}$, not $\frac{f^{(n+1)}(a)}{(n+1)!}x^{n+1}$?

To compute the derivative of the Taylor series we would like to go from $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}x^n$ to $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-1)!}x^{n-1}$. Assuming that the former is represented by the symmetric form $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}x_1 x_2 \dots x_n$, we can set $x_n=1$ (derivative in $x$ is derivative in the direction $1$) and multiply by $n$ to get $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-1)!}x_1 x_2 \dots x_{n-1}$, which evaluates to $\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-1)!}x^{n-1}$ as desired. However, this factor of $n$ is nowhere to be seen in the definition of `shift`. Also if it's not a symmetric form, you would omit each $x_i$ and sum the $n$ terms together, which is done in `changeOriginSeries 1`.

Am I missing something? Let's ask the other author @urkud of [mathlib3#5878](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/commit/547d67fc7ad1ae9f0df0be5b64ac531c0dd5f4ca#diff-6090aa57561906639f8792a3240c2309c9e75b9900d9bb114e51f5cba12eab22R918-R925) to take a look.

Sorry, I'm attributing to the wrong PR. The use of changeOriginSeries comes from [mathlib3#13127](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/13127/files#diff-9a817f37e79c130ec39ff3455a5d5e282d63c9c86cee556db0183151eb46216fR77-R81) which was authored by @sgouezel alone.

Okay, I looked up how `shift` is [used in mathlib](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/a59d0136f417dcbf1d9fceaa2d42ed87d592a164/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.lean#L560) and I think I now get where the confusion stems from. I think the "Taylor series" in the docstring refers to [HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.html#HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn), where the $n$-th term of the FormalMultilinearSeries is the "tensor of iterated/mixed $n$-th-order partial derivatives". (Each term should be symmetric under the ContDiff condition due to [symmetry of second derivatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_of_second_derivatives), but I don't know whether we have the general result in mathlib.)

Evaluating this series doesn't give you back the original function though (even if the function is analytic): the $n$-th term needs to be divided by $n!$ for that. So I'd say the docstring is true with an unconventional definition of "Taylor series". If we add a link to [`HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.html#HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn) I think we can keep the docstring.

And my other confusion (which led to my "doesn't typecheck" comment) comes from the difference between the derivatives that we had in mind: in the setting of [HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.html#HasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn), the derivative of a function from `E` to `E^n â†’L[k] F` is an element of `E^{n+1} â†’L[k] F`. But in the setting of [HasFPowerSeriesOnBall](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#HasFPowerSeriesOnBall), the derivative of the evaluation of a continuous multilinear function `E^n â†’L[k] F` on the diagonal is the evaluation of other continuous multilinear function `E^{n-1} â†’L[k] (E â†’L[k] F)` on the diagonal.
I opened #9373 for the docs clarification.

When I say "`f` has `p` as a Taylor series up to order `n`", I mean it in the sense of [HasFTaylorSeriesUpTo](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.html#HasFTaylorSeriesUpTo), i.e., `p 0` is equal to `f`, and `p (n+1)` is the derivative of `p n`. In this sense, a Taylor series is a gadget recording the sequence of derivatives of a function. The fact that `p.shift` is a Taylor series, in this sense, for the derivative of `f`, is for instance recorded in [hasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn_succ_iff_right](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/Defs.html#hasFTaylorSeriesUpToOn_succ_iff_right)
@smorel394, could you have a look at #9373 to see if you think the clarification of the docs is good enough for you, or if you think you can make it even better for future users?
It looks good to me.

> Regarding the connection with linearDeriv, maybe the most general thing we can state and prove is that `linearDeriv` evaluate to the same thing as the `changeOriginSeries 1` of `toFormalMultilinearSeriesFixedDegree`. (Regarding the definition of `toFormalMultilinearSeriesFixedDegree`: I think you need to sum over powersetCard because you want a series development around an arbitrary point, but I think you can just define the series around the origin, which would just be a single term (a "homogeneous" CPolynomial), and then use changeOrigin of FormalMultilinearSeries rather than repeating the work.)

This is really about PR #9130, I'm making changes there to answer your suggestion.

Done, I've also rewritten the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic in [another project](https://github.com/smorel394/ExteriorPowers/blob/master/ExteriorPowers/ContinuousMultilinearMapContDiff.lean). The applications to differentiability require completeness right now, but only until this PR is merged.

I got rid of the formal multilinear series stuff in #9130, since the definition of the formal multilinear series at 0 is so basic and can be done very quickly when needed. The proof that the `fderiv` is equal to the degree 1 of `changeOrigin` of the formal multilinear series at 0 is a bit messy for now, but at least it compiles, and I'm sure I can make it shorter.

I've now shown that if a function has any power series on a ball, then its Taylor series (with the 1/n! factor) does converge to the function on the ball, [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/The.20Taylor.20series.20of.20an.20entire.20function.20converges.20to.20it/near/417334632). However, in order to show that the Taylor series satisfies the HasFPowerSeriesOnBall perdicate, we need to bound the growth of the norms of the terms in the series, which would require a polarization identity.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic): continuously polynomial functions

nodes.body: Just pushed some improvements. Here are comments on what I did:

> Ok oops, the file Polynomial.lean already existed in that directory. I'm surprised that vscode didn't protest when I tried to create a new file with that name.

The file was just merged into mathlib yesterday and wasn't in your local copy of mathlib, so no wonder VSCode doesn't complain ... It's about evaluations of Polynomial and MvPolynomial rather than MultilinearMap or Series, so you did the right thing to create a new file CPolynomial. I should have suggested the name CPolynomial earlier, because it's me who added the Polynomial file ... ðŸ˜…

> > Ok oops, the file Polynomial.lean already existed in that directory. I'm surprised that vscode didn't protest when I tried to create a new file with that name.
> 
> The file was just merged into mathlib yesterday and wasn't in your local copy of mathlib, so no wonder VSCode doesn't complain ... It's about evaluations of Polynomial and MvPolynomial rather than MultilinearMap or Series, so you did the right thing to create a new file CPolynomial. I should have suggested the name CPolynomial earlier, because it's me who added the Polynomial file ... ðŸ˜…

But do you understand why all the CI checks fail now ? My files compile locally, but now the "check that all files are imported" check fails, and then mathlib doesn't build. As I don't know what "check that all files are imported means", I am kind of stuck.
Also, the file `Polynomial.lean` should really prove that polynomials are `CPolynomial`, not just analytic, then you'll get infinite differentiability even if `B` is not complete.
Well I merged with master, I tried pushing again, CI still fails with an error message I don't understand...
Yeah it was the import in Calculus.FDeriv.Analytic, wasn't it. I finally figured it out, but looks like you got there just before me...
I think you also need to add the CPolynomial file to Mathlib.lean.
Oh, is that something that you need to do every time you add a new file ? Good to know.

If you click on the second "detail" you'll be led to [this page](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7350472056/job/20012191648?pr=9269) which shows what needs to be done. I think the bot used to suggest such fixes ...
I did click on the "details" page, but I didn't see any information that I could understand...
Yes it's not totally clear. It's presented in the form of a diff for you to apply, like the bot's [suggestion](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9269#discussion_r1437840750).
Also, CI still fails, and the bot seems to be suggesting that I remove CPolynomial from Mathlib.lean, or switch the order? It's making several suggestions and they don't seem very compatible.

> Yes it's not totally clear. It's presented in the form of a diff for you to apply, like the bot's [suggestion](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9269#discussion_r1437840750). Okay, well, now I see what you mean, but there was no way I was going to understand that on my own... I guess I'll know next time.
So let's see if I understand the suggestion this time. I think it wants me to move a line around. I thought the imports were in alphabetical order, but apparently not.

Minor comments about docstrings. Otherwise, let's get this merged.

bors d+
